articles.headline: Should we “get it through our thick skulls” that oil and gas are part of the climate change solution?
articles.description: J.P. Morgan chief executive Jamie Dimon says increasing oil and gas production in the US does not conflict with long-term climate change action goals.
articles.introParagraph: J.P. Morgan chief executive Jamie Dimon recently said increasing oil and gas production in the US does not conflict with long-term climate change action goals.

content.value: "We should focus on climate. The problem with that is because of high oil and gas prices, the world is turning back on their coal plants. It is dirtier,"
Yahoo
reported Dimon said in a client call.
"Why can't we get it through our thick skulls, that if you want to solve climate [change], it is not against climate [change] for America to boost more oil and gas?"
It’s not the first time Dimon has expressed these views.

“Oil and gas supply can be easily disrupted, either physically or by additional sanctions, significantly impacting energy prices. National security demands energy security for ourselves and for our allies overseas,” Dimon said in a letter to J.P. Morgan shareholders last year.

“Fortunately, we do not need to change our long-term objectives on climate change and greenhouse gases, and we should remind ourselves that using gas to diminish coal consumption is an actionable way to reduce CO2 emissions expeditiously.”
Future Super chief impact officer Emily Flood argues Dimon is plain wrong in his understanding of the emissions that cause climate change.
She points out that while Dimon refers to CO2 emissions, he’s conveniently directing attention away from the other greenhouse gas emissions that cause climate change.
Research from the
European Space Agency has used satellite data

to understand how methane emissions from oil and gas production compare to the emissions from coal, finding that methane leaks along the gas chain offset the climate benefits of switching from burning coal to natural gas.
Executive director of the UN Environment Programme
Inger Anderson has said
: “Cutting methane emissions is the best way to slow climate change over the next 25 years.”

That’s because methane has 80 times the warming impact of carbon dioxide for the first 20 years after it is released and because methane from the oil and gas supply chain accounts for 23% of emissions, while coal mining accounts for 12%.
Flood says Dimon’s claims that oil and gas production can be part of the climate change solution are a “classic greenwashing move.”

“Jamie Dimon is running a company that has over US $4.3 billion invested in coal and US $76.8 billion in oil and gas. He’s claimed that the US should boost investment into oil and gas and greenlight new projects,” she says.

“This is, of course, directly against the recommendations of expert bodies such as the International Energy Agency (IEA) and the recent IPCC reports, which all agree that absolutely no further expansion or new projects for coal, oil or gas should be approved.”

Flood added that the vast networks of researchers and scientists working for these agencies have developed multiple guidelines for achieving how investors, governments and industries need to adapt to the challenges posed by anthropogenic global warming - and still people like Dimon believe they know better.
“J.P. Morgan, the company itself, has a net zero commitment that discusses the need to transition away from fossil fuels,” Flood points out.
“But obviously, Jamie Dimon has no skin in the game whatsoever when he talks about the attractiveness of expanding fossil fuel activities in the US.”

J.P. Morgan is one of the largest fossil fuel financiers in the world. According to a recent report from climate change think tank InfluenceMap, J.P Morgan poured US $81 billion into fossil fuel projects in 2020-2021 alone.

InfluenceMap looked at 30 international banks which finance fossil fuel production, finding 29 of them - including J.P. Morgan - have set net zero by 2050 targets. The ongoing financing of fossil fuels by these institutions suggests others may share Dimon’s views that emissions reductions can coexist with fossil fuel production expansion.

For this reason, Flood adds that Dimon has a financial incentive to allay any fears J.P. Morgan investors might have that fossil fuel assets may become stranded assets, and result in losses, if governments intervene to act on climate change.

“He’s just a nice guy, who’s never heard of methane and just assumes that there will be buyers on the other side of the deal when he wants to walk away from fossil fuels once governments start to transition to renewable energy and demand drops off,” Flood says.
“He’s definitely got a plan. Nothing to see here.”

articles.description: Climate change etc things blah blah
articles.introParagraph: The government has committed to reviewing Australia’s “sham” carbon credit system after a whistleblower revealed that up to 80% of Australian carbon credits are fraudulent.

content.value: The Albanese government kicked off an independent review of Australia’s carbon credits system shortly after winning the election, in response to a whistleblower alleging up to 80% of carbon credits in Australia are a “sham”.

Andrew Macintosh is a professor at Australian National University and has worked in climate policy for more than 20 years. Among many other roles he chaired the Domestic Offsets and Integrity Committee, which oversees the method for the carbon trading scheme, for six and a half years. Macintosh has been a part of establishing the carbon trading system in Australia, is embedded in Australia’s climate policy world and is a believer in environmental markets.
What are carbon credits?
Last year, the Wilmot Cattle Company - based in Ebor, on the Northern Tablelands of NSW - made a groundbreaking deal with Microsoft.

articles.headline: Why investing in cars isn't that bad for the planet
articles.description: We look at companies who are leading their industry on carbon intensity
articles.introParagraph: The government has committed to reviewing Australia’s “sham” carbon credit system after a whistleblower revealed that up to 80% of Australian carbon credits are fraudulent.

content.value: The Albanese government kicked off an independent review of Australia’s carbon credits system shortly after winning the election, in response to a whistleblower alleging up to 80% of carbon credits in Australia are a “sham”.

Andrew Macintosh is a professor at Australian National University and has worked in climate policy for more than 20 years. Among many other roles he chaired the Domestic Offsets and Integrity Committee, which oversees the method for the carbon trading scheme, for six and a half years. Macintosh has been a part of establishing the carbon trading system in Australia, is embedded in Australia’s climate policy world and is a believer in environmental markets.

He’s now turned whistleblower though. He is calling for the Clean Energy Regulator, which regulates Australian Carbon Credit Units to be broken up, citing serious conflicts of interest and a history of low-integrity management.
What are carbon credits?
Last year, the Wilmot Cattle Company - based in Ebor, on the Northern Tablelands of NSW - made a groundbreaking deal with Microsoft.

articles.headline: The weird, shady world of carbon credits
articles.description: How a beef company and Rupert Murdoch’s son-in-law became climate change warriors. Or did they?
articles.introParagraph: The government has committed to reviewing Australia’s “sham” carbon credit system after a whistleblower revealed that up to 80% of Australian carbon credits are fraudulent.

content.value: The Albanese government kicked off an independent review of Australia’s carbon credits system shortly after winning the election, in response to a whistleblower alleging up to 80% of carbon credits in Australia are a “sham”.

Andrew Macintosh is a professor at Australian National University and has worked in climate policy for more than 20 years. Among many other roles he chaired the Domestic Offsets and Integrity Committee, which oversees the method for the carbon trading scheme, for six and a half years. Macintosh has been a part of establishing the carbon trading system in Australia, is embedded in Australia’s climate policy world and is a believer in environmental markets.

He’s now turned whistleblower though. He is calling for the Clean Energy Regulator, which regulates Australian Carbon Credit Units to be broken up, citing serious conflicts of interest and a history of low-integrity management.
What are carbon credits?
Last year, the Wilmot Cattle Company - based in Ebor, on the Northern Tablelands of NSW - made a groundbreaking deal with Microsoft.
